item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
@Adam -
Well, at least there are a few options out there now. I'm not sure that they work very well with each other though. There really needs to be a simple email tags spec so that things work as expected.
item.content:encoded:
@Adam –

Well, at least there are a few options out there now. I’m not sure that they work very well with each other though. There really needs to be a simple email tags spec so that things work as expected.

item.content:encoded: I was just driving home from work tonight and twittered this exact question!

item.title: By: Greg Nelson
item.dc:creator: Greg Nelson
item.description:
Taglocity (www.taglocity.com) has a free/commercial Outlook Add-In for tagging. It has some really nice features such as a tag cloud, Bayesian learning for auto-tagging, tag renaming, etc.
I have been testing interoperability between TB's tagging feature and the Taglocity plugin, and found a somewhat annoying compatibility issue:
TB stores its tags in the "Tags" element of the header, while Taglocity uses the "Keywords" element! Meaning, of course, that tags aren't cross-recognized on the two platforms.
Anyone know a fix for this?
item.content:encoded:
Taglocity (www.taglocity.com) has a free/commercial Outlook Add-In for tagging. It has some really nice features such as a tag cloud, Bayesian learning for auto-tagging, tag renaming, etc.

I have been testing interoperability between TB’s tagging feature and the Taglocity plugin, and found a somewhat annoying compatibility issue:

TB stores its tags in the “Tags” element of the header, while
Taglocity uses the “Keywords” element! Meaning, of course, that tags aren’t cross-recognized on the two platforms.

Anyone know a fix for this?

item.title: By: Danny Michel
item.dc:creator: Danny Michel
item.description: This sounds like a great idea. I would love to have this as a plugin feature on outlook./ Hey maybe you can even go open source with it and so something for Thunderbird just to get the idea popular.
item.content:encoded:
This sounds like a great idea.

item.title: By: John
item.dc:creator: John
item.description: Mark's idea of using Categories (from the preview pane, highlight the email or emails you want to tag and choose Edit-Categories and assign the Category). You can then sort or search for the messages by Category. I had no idea to try this, but Mark is my hero!
item.content:encoded: Mark’s idea of using Categories (from the preview pane, highlight the email or emails you want to tag and choose Edit-Categories and assign the Category). You can then sort or search for the messages by Category. I had no idea to try this, but Mark is my hero!

item.title: By: Some guy
item.dc:creator: Some guy
item.description: https://addons.mozilla.org/thunderbird/1832/ Tag the Bird extension for Thunderbird adds tagging in an X-Tags header. The extension itself lacks a few features, but overall seems to work well enough for me at the moment. Easy tag adding and editing.
item.content:encoded: https://addons.mozilla.org/thunderbird/1832/ Tag the Bird extension for Thunderbird adds tagging in an X-Tags header. The extension itself lacks a few features, but overall seems to work well enough for me at the moment. Easy tag adding and editing.

item.title: By: Kim
item.dc:creator: Kim
item.description:
Wow, this is so awesome! I am a soon to be graduate in Information Technology and I have been tossing this email and file tagging/labeling/keywording idea around since I started designing databases in Access almost ten years ago. Databases make indexing and searching a natural way of life to support views and queries, and I thought to myself, "Well, why don't they make that for files and emails?" Just keep them all in one place (like a table, not in silly folders) and have searches (views or queries) to filter out the files/emails you need with whatever subject or keywords at any given point in time. Then you don't have to worry where you're filing crap - or file it at all! My over 10,000 emails at home could use such a system.
I was so happy when I found out GMail and Vista support it. Filing in file folders is thinking in PHYSICAL concepts! It's about time we thought electronically!
So there's my two cents. Sorry I can't contribute to your project personally, but I thank everyone involved...if it's still going on...
item.content:encoded:
Wow, this is so awesome! I am a soon to be graduate in Information Technology and I have been tossing this email and file tagging/labeling/keywording idea around since I started designing databases in Access almost ten years ago. Databases make indexing and searching a natural way of life to support views and queries, and I thought to myself, “Well, why don’t they make that for files and emails?” Just keep them all in one place (like a table, not in silly folders) and have searches (views or queries) to filter out the files/emails you need with whatever subject or keywords at any given point in time. Then you don’t have to worry where you’re filing crap – or file it at all! My over 10,000 emails at home could use such a system.

I was so happy when I found out GMail and Vista support it. Filing in file folders is thinking in PHYSICAL concepts! It’s about time we thought electronically!

So there’s my two cents. Sorry I can’t contribute to your project personally, but I thank everyone involved…if it’s still going on…
